verses.roman:
yogīndrāya namas tasmai
śukāya brahma-rūpiṇe
saṁsāra-sarpa-daṣṭaṁ yo
viṣṇu-rātam amūmucat

synonyms: yogi-indrāya—to the king of mystics; namaḥ—obeisances; tasmai—to him; śukaya—Śukadeva Gosvāmī; brahma-rūpiṇe—who is a personal manifestation of the Absolute Truth; saṁsāra-sarpa—by the snake of material existence; daṣṭam—bitten; yaḥ—who; viṣṇu-rātam—Parīkṣit Mahārāja; amūmucat—freed.
translation: I offer my humble obeisances to Śrī Śukadeva Gosvāmī, the best of mystic sages and a personal manifestation of the Absolute Truth. He saved Mahārāja Parīkṣit, who was bitten by the snake of material existence.

purport.content: Sūta Gosvāmī now offers obeisances to his own spiritual master Śukadeva Gosvāmī. Śrīla Viśvanātha Cakravartī Ṭhākura clarifies that just as Arjuna was placed into material confusion so that Bhagavad-gītā might be spoken, so King Parīkṣit, a pure, liberated devotee of the Lord, was cursed to die so that Śrīmad-Bhāgavatam might be spoken. Actually, King Parīkṣit is viṣṇu-rāta, eternally under the protection of the Lord. Śukadeva Gosvāmī liberated the king from his so-called illusion to exhibit the merciful nature of a pure devotee and the enlightening effect of his association.
